channel.title: The Economist - World in Brief
channel.description: Catch up quickly on the global stories that matter

item.title: World in Brief - February 12, 2026
item.description:
America’s House of Representatives voted in favour of ending the national emergency that Donald Trump invoked to impose tariffs on Canadian imports last year. The measure now goes to the Senate, though the president will probably veto it if it reaches his desk. Still, the House vote is a symbolic rebuke of Mr Trump’s trade policies, with six Republicans joining Democrats to support the resolution.

Police identified Jesse Van Rootselaar, an 18-year-old transgender woman, as the suspected shooter in an attack on a school and nearby residence in the Canadian province of British Columbia. Nine people were killed in the shooting, including the attacker, who turned the gun on herself. Earlier authorities said that at least 25 other people were injured. A motive has yet to be confirmed.

America’s economy added 130,000 jobs in January, almost double the number that analysts had been expecting, indicating that the labour market might have picked up after a difficult few months. The unemployment rate also fell to 4.3%, a slight dip from the previous month. The figures may discourage the Federal Reserve from lowering interest rates as fast as Mr Trump would like.

Italy’s government passed a bill authorising the use of naval blockades to stop migrants entering the country. The measure—championed by Giorgia Meloni, Italy’s populist prime minister—would be rolled out when there is a surge of migrants attempting to reach the country’s shores. Earlier this week European Union lawmakers approved new measures to counter illegal immigration, including swifter repatriation.

Following a meeting with Binyamin Netanyahu in Washington, Mr Trump said “nothing definitive” was decided about dealing with Iran’s nuclear programme, but that negotiations with the Islamic Republic would continue. Earlier, during a speech to mark the 47th anniversary of the Islamic revolution, Iran’s president said he was prepared to allow nuclear inspections, and reiterated that the country was not building an atomic weapon.

Pershing Square, a hedge fund run by Bill Ackman, an activist investor, disclosed a stake in Meta worth around 10% of the fund’s capital. Mr Ackman said investors’ fears about Meta’s heavy spending on AI had undervalued the company, and that it stands to benefit from the technology. Earlier Meta announced that it had begun construction on a $10bn data centre in Indiana.

Kraft Heinz paused plans to split into two companies. The struggling American food giant originally announced in September that it would break up its slow-growing store brands from its seasonings and sauces business. Steve Cahillane, Kraft Heinz’s new boss, said the company’s problems were “fixable” and would instead invest $600m to beef up its marketing efforts and product offerings.
